column2: The majestic outline of the Louvre seemed to frown sarcastically on her weakness, the silent river to mock her and her wavering purpose.
column3: The majestic outline of the Louvre seemed to frown sarcastically on her weakness, the silent river to mock her and her wavering purpose.

column2: The man beside her had wronged her and hers far more deeply than the Bourbons had wronged their people.
column3: The man beside her had wronged her and hers far more deeply than the Bourbons had wronged their people.

column2: The people of France were taking their revenge, and God had at the close of this last happy day of her life pointed once more to the means for her great end.
column3: The people of France were taking their revenge, and God had at the close of this last happy day of her life pointed once more to the means for her great end.

column2: CHAPTER VI
column3: CHAPTER six

column2: The Scarlet Pimpernel.
column3: The Scarlet Pimpernel.

column2: It was some few hours later.
column3: It was some few hours later.

column2: The ladies sat in the drawing-room, silent and anxious.
column3: The ladies sat in the drawing room, silent and anxious.

column2: Soon after supper a visitor had called, and had been closeted with Paul Deroulede in the latter's study for the past two hours.
column3: Soon after supper a visitor had called, and had been closeted with Paul Deroulede in the latter's study for the past two hours.

column2: A tall, somewhat lazy-looking figure, he was sitting at a table face to face with the Citizen-Deputy.
column3: A tall, somewhat lazy looking figure, he was sitting at a table face to face with the Citizen Deputy.

column2: On a chair beside him lay a heavy caped coat, covered with the dust and the splashings of a long journey, but he himself was attired in clothes that suggested the most fastidious taste, and the most perfect of tailors; he wore with apparent ease the eccentric fashion of the time, the short-waisted coat of many lapels, the double waistcoat and billows of delicate lace.
column3: On a chair beside him lay a heavy caped coat, covered with the dust and the splashings of a long journey, but he himself was attired in clothes that suggested the most fastidious taste, and the most perfect of tailors; he wore with apparent ease the eccentric fashion of the time, the short waisted coat of many lapels, the double waistcoat and billows of delicate lace.

column2: Unlike Deroulede he was of great height, with fair hair and a somewhat lazy expression in his good-natured blue eyes, and as he spoke, there was just a soupcon of foreign accent in the pronunciation of the French vowels, a certain drawl of o's and a's, that would have betrayed the Britisher to an observant ear.
column3: Unlike Deroulede he was of great height, with fair hair and a somewhat lazy expression in his good-natured blue eyes, and as he spoke, there was just a soupcon of foreign accent in the pronunciation of the French vowels, a certain drawl of o's and a's, that would have betrayed the Britisher to an observant ear.

column2: The two men had been talking earnestly for some time, the tall Englishman was watching his friend keenly, whilst an amused, pleasant smile lingered round the corners of his firm mouth and jaw.
column3: The two men had been talking earnestly for some time, the tall Englishman was watching his friend keenly, whilst an amused, pleasant smile lingered round the corners of his firm mouth and jaw.

column2: Deroulede, restless and enthusiastic, was pacing to and fro.
column3: Deroulede, restless and enthusiastic, was pacing to and fro.

column2: But I don't understand now, how you managed to reach Paris, my dear Blakeney! said Deroulede at last, placing an anxious hand on his friend's shoulder.
column3: But I don't understand now, how you managed to reach Paris, my dear Blakeney! said Deroulede at last, placing an anxious hand on his friend's shoulder.

column2: The government has not forgotten The Scarlet Pimpernel.
column3: The government has not forgotten The Scarlet Pimpernel.

column2: La!	La!
column3: true

column2: I took care of that!" responded Blakeney with his short, pleasant laugh.
column3: I took care of that!" responded Blakeney with his short, pleasant laugh.

column2: I sent Tinville my autograph this morning.
column3: I sent Tinville my autograph this morning.

column2: You are mad, Blakeney!
column3: You are mad, Blakeney!

column2: Not altogether, my friend.	Not altogether, my friend.
column3: true

column2: My faith!
column3: My faith!

column2: 'twas on only foolhardiness caused me to grant that devilish prosecutor another sight of my scarlet device. I knew what you maniacs would be after, so I came across in the _Daydream,_just to see if I couldn't get my share of the fun."
column3: 'twas on only foolhardiness caused me to grant that devilish prosecutor another sight of my scarlet device. I knew what you maniacs would be after, so I came across in the underscore Daydream,underscore just to see if I couldn't get my share of the fun."

column2: Fun, you call it? queried the other bitterly.
column3: Fun, you call it? queried the other bitterly.

column2: Nay! what would you have me call it?	Nay! what would you have me call it?
column3: false

column2: A mad, insane, senseless tragedy, with but one issue?--the guillotine for you all."
column3: A mad, insane, senseless tragedy, with but one issue?--the guillotine for you all."

column2: Then why did you come?
column3: Then why did you come?

column2: To--What shall I say, my friend? rejoined Sir Percy Blakeney, with that inimitable drawl of his.
column3: To-What shall I say, my friend? rejoined Sir Percy Blakeney, with that inimitable drawl of his.

column2: To give your demmed government something else to think about, whilst you are all busy running your heads into a noose.
column3: To give your demmed government something else to think about, whilst you are all busy running your heads into a noose.

column2: What makes you think we are doing that?
column3: What makes you think we are doing that?

column2: Three things, my friend--may I offer you a pinch of snuff--No?--Ah well!... And with the graceful gesture of an accomplished dandy, Sir Percy flicked off a grain of dust from his immaculate Mechlin ruffles.
column3: Three things, my friend-may I offer you a pinch of snuff-No?--Ah well!... And with the graceful gesture of an accomplished dandy, Sir Percy flicked off a grain of dust from his immaculate Mechlin ruffles.

column2: Three things, he continued quietly; "an imprisoned Queen, about to be tried for her life, the temperament of a Frenchman--some of them--and the idiocy of mankind generally.
column3: Three things, he continued quietly; "an imprisoned Queen, about to be tried for her life, the temperament of a Frenchman-some of them-and the idiocy of mankind generally.

column2: These three things make me think that a certain section of hot-headed Republicans with yourself, my dear Deroulede, _en tete,_ are about to attempt the most stupid, senseless, purposeless thing that was ever concocted by the excitable brain of a demmed Frenchman."
column3: These three things make me think that a certain section of hot headed Republicans with yourself, my dear Deroulede, underscore en tete,underscore are about to attempt the most stupid, senseless, purposeless thing that was ever concocted by the excitable brain of a demmed Frenchman."

column2: Deroulede smiled.
column3: Deroulede smiled.

column2: Does it not seem amusing to you, Blakeney, that you should sit there and condemn anyone for planning mad, insane, senseless things.
column3: Does it not seem amusing to you, Blakeney, that you should sit there and condemn anyone for planning mad, insane, senseless things.

column2: La!	La!
column3: false

column2: I'll not sit, I'll stand!" rejoined Blakeney with a laugh, as he drew himself up to his full height, and stretched his long, lazy limbs. "And now let me tell you, friend, that my League of The Scarlet Pimpernel never attempted the impossible, and to try and drag the Queen out of the clutches of these murderous rascals now, is attempting the unattainable."
column3: I'll not sit, I'll stand!" rejoined Blakeney with a laugh, as he drew himself up to his full height, and stretched his long, lazy limbs. "And now let me tell you, friend, that my League of The Scarlet Pimpernel never attempted the impossible, and to try and drag the Queen out of the clutches of these murderous rascals now, is attempting the unattainable."

column2: And yet we mean to try.
column3: And yet we mean to try.

column2: I know it.	I know it.
column3: true

column2: I guessed it, that is why I came: that is also why I sent a pleasant little note to the Committee of Public Safety, signed with the device they know so well: The Scarlet Pimpernel."
column3: I guessed it, that is why I came: that is also why I sent a pleasant little note to the Committee of Public Safety, signed with the device they know so well: The Scarlet Pimpernel."

column2: Well?
column3: Well?

column2: Well! the result is obvious.	Well! the result is obvious.
column3: true

column2: Robespierre, Danton, Tinville, Merlin, and the whole of the demmed murderous crowd, will be busy looking after me--a needle in a haystack.
column3: Robespierre, Danton, Tinville, Merlin, and the whole of the demmed murderous crowd, will be busy looking after me-a needle in a haystack.

column2: They'll put the abortive attempt down to me, and you may--_ma foi!_ I only suggest that you _may_ escape safely out of France--in the _Daydream,_ and with the help of your humble servant."
column3: They'll put the abortive attempt down to me, and you may-underscore ma foi!underscore I only suggest that you underscore may underscore escape safely out of France-in the underscore Daydream,underscore and with the help of your humble servant."

column2: But in the meanwhile they'll discover you, and they'll not let you escape a second time.
column3: But in the meanwhile they'll discover you, and they'll not let you escape a second time.

column2: My friend! if a terrier were to lose his temper, he never would run a rat to earth.	My friend! if a terrier were to lose his temper, he never would run a rat to earth.
column3: true

column2: Now your Revolutionary Government has lost its temper with me, ever since I slipped through Chauvelin's fingers; they are blind with their own fury, whilst I am perfectly happy and cool as a cucumber. My life has become valuable to me, my friend.
column3: Now your Revolutionary Government has lost its temper with me, ever since I slipped through Chauvelin's fingers; they are blind with their own fury, whilst I am perfectly happy and cool as a cucumber. My life has become valuable to me, my friend.

column2: There is someone over the water now who weeps when I don't return--No! no! never fear--they'll not get The Scarlet Pimpernel this journey ..."
column3: There is someone over the water now who weeps when I don't return-No! no! never fear-they'll not get The Scarlet Pimpernel this journey ..."

column2: He laughed, a gay, pleasant laugh, and his strong, firm face seemed to soften at thought of the beautiful wife, over in England, who was waiting anxiously for his safe return.
column3: He laughed, a gay, pleasant laugh, and his strong, firm face seemed to soften at thought of the beautiful wife, over in England, who was waiting anxiously for his safe return.

column2: And yet you'll not help us to rescue the Queen? rejoined Deroulede, with some bitterness.
column3: And yet you'll not help us to rescue the Queen? rejoined Deroulede, with some bitterness.

column2: By every means in my power, replied Blakeney, "save the insane.
column3: By every means in my power, replied Blakeney, "save the insane.

column2: But I will help to get you all out of the demmed hole, when you have failed."
column3: But I will help to get you all out of the demmed hole, when you have failed."

column2: We'll not fail, asserted the other hotly.
column3: We'll not fail, asserted the other hotly.

column2: Sir Percy Blakeney went close up to his friend and placed his long, slender hand, with a touch of almost womanly tenderness upon the latter's shoulder.
column3: Sir Percy Blakeney went close up to his friend and placed his long, slender hand, with a touch of almost womanly tenderness upon the latter's shoulder.

column2: Will you tell me your plans?
column3: Will you tell me your plans?

column2: In a moment Deroulede was all fire and enthusiasm.
column3: In a moment Deroulede was all fire and enthusiasm.

column2: There are not many of us in it, he began, "although half France will be in sympathy with us.
column3: There are not many of us in it, he began, "although half France will be in sympathy with us.

column2: We have plenty of money, of course, and also the necessary disguise for the royal lady."
column3: We have plenty of money, of course, and also the necessary disguise for the royal lady."

column2: Yes?
column3: Yes?

column2: I, in the meanwhile, have asked for and obtained the post of Governor of the Conciergerie; I go into my new quarters to-morrow.	I, in the meanwhile, have asked for and obtained the post of Governor of the Conciergerie; I go into my new quarters to morrow.
column3: false

column2: In the meanwhile, I am making arrangements for my mother and--and those dependent upon me to quit France immediately."
column3: In the meanwhile, I am making arrangements for my mother and-and those dependent upon me to quit France immediately."

column2: Blakeney had perceived the slight hesitation when Deroulede mentioned those dependent upon him.
column3: Blakeney had perceived the slight hesitation when Deroulede mentioned those dependent upon him.

column2: He looked scrutinisingly at his friend, who continued quickly:
column3: He looked scrutinisingly at his friend, who continued quickly:

column2: I am still very popular among the people.	I am still very popular among the people.
column3: true

column2: My family can go about unmolested.
column3: My family can go about unmolested.

column2: I must get them out of France, however, in case--in case ..."
column3: I must get them out of France, however, in case-in case ..."

column2: Of course, rejoined the other simply.
column3: Of course, rejoined the other simply.

column2: As soon as I am assured that they are safe, my friends and I can prosecute our plans.	As soon as I am assured that they are safe, my friends and I can prosecute our plans.
column3: false

column2: You see the trial of the Queen has not yet been decided on, but I know that it is in the air.
column3: You see the trial of the Queen has not yet been decided on, but I know that it is in the air.

column2: We hope to get her away, disguised in one of the uniforms of the National Guard.
column3: We hope to get her away, disguised in one of the uniforms of the National Guard.

column2: As you know, it will be my duty to make the final round every evening in the prison, and to see that everything is safe for the night.
column3: As you know, it will be my duty to make the final round every evening in the prison, and to see that everything is safe for the night.

column2: Two fellows watch all night, in the room next to that occupied by the Queen.
column3: Two fellows watch all night, in the room next to that occupied by the Queen.

column2: Usually they drink and play cards all night long.
column3: Usually they drink and play cards all night long.

column2: I want an opportunity to drug their brandy, and thus to render them more loutish and idiotic than usual; then for a blow on the head that will make them senseless.
column3: I want an opportunity to drug their brandy, and thus to render them more loutish and idiotic than usual; then for a blow on the head that will make them senseless.

column2: It should be easy, for I have a strong fist, and after that ..."
column3: It should be easy, for I have a strong fist, and after that ..."

column2: Well?	Well?
column3: true

column2: After that, friend?" rejoined Sir Percy earnestly, "after that? Shall I fill in the details of the picture?--the guard twenty-five strong outside the Conciergerie, how will you pass them?"
column3: After that, friend?" rejoined Sir Percy earnestly, "after that? Shall I fill in the details of the picture?--the guard twenty five strong outside the Conciergerie, how will you pass them?"

column2: I as the Governor, followed by one of my guards ...
column3: I as the Governor, followed by one of my guards ...

column2: To go whither?
column3: To go whither?

column2: I have the right to come and go as I please.
column3: I have the right to come and go as I please.

column2: I' faith! so you have, but 'one of your guards'--eh?	I' faith! so you have, but 'one of your guards'--eh?
column3: false

column2: Wrapped to the eyes in a long mantle to hide the female figure beneath.
column3: Wrapped to the eyes in a long mantle to hide the female figure beneath.

column2: I have been in Paris but a few hours, and yet already I have realised that there is not one demmed citizen within its walls, who does not at this moment suspect some other demmed citizen of conniving at the Queen's escape.
column3: I have been in Paris but a few hours, and yet already I have realised that there is not one demmed citizen within its walls, who does not at this moment suspect some other demmed citizen of conniving at the Queen's escape.

column2: Even the sparrows on the house-tops are objects of suspicion.
column3: Even the sparrows on the house tops are objects of suspicion.

column2: No figure wrapped in a mantle will from this day forth leave Paris unchallenged."
column3: No figure wrapped in a mantle will from this day forth leave Paris unchallenged."

column2: But you yourself, friend? suggested Deroulede.
column3: But you yourself, friend? suggested Deroulede.

column2: You think you can quit Paris unrecognised--then why not the Queen?
column3: You think you can quit Paris unrecognised-then why not the Queen?

column2: Because she is a woman, and has been a queen.	Because she is a woman, and has been a queen.
column3: true

column2: She has nerves, poor soul, and weaknesses of body and of mind now.
column3: She has nerves, poor soul, and weaknesses of body and of mind now.

column2: Alas for her!
column3: Alas for her!

column2: Alas for France! who wreaks such idle vengeance on so poor an enemy?
column3: Alas for France! who wreaks such idle vengeance on so poor an enemy?

column2: Can you take hold of Marie Antoinette by the shoulders, shove her into the bottom of a cart and pile sacks of potatoes on the top of her?
column3: Can you take hold of Marie Antoinette by the shoulders, shove her into the bottom of a cart and pile sacks of potatoes on the top of her?

column2: I did that to the Comtesse de Tournai and her daughter, as stiff-necked a pair of French aristocrats as ever deserved the guillotine for their insane prejudices. But can you do it to Marie Antoinette?
column3: I did that to the Comtesse de Tournai and her daughter, as stiff necked a pair of French aristocrats as ever deserved the guillotine for their insane prejudices. But can you do it to Marie Antoinette?

column2: She'd rebuke you publicly, and betray herself and you in a flash, sooner than submit to a loss of dignity."
column3: She'd rebuke you publicly, and betray herself and you in a flash, sooner than submit to a loss of dignity."

column2: But would you leave her to her fate?
column3: But would you leave her to her fate?

column2: Ah! there's the trouble, friend.	Ah! there's the trouble, friend.
column3: true

column2: Do you think you need appeal to the sense of chivalry of my league?
column3: Do you think you need appeal to the sense of chivalry of my league?

column2: We are still twenty strong, and heart and soul in sympathy with your mad schemes.
column3: We are still twenty strong, and heart and soul in sympathy with your mad schemes.

column2: The poor, poor Queen!
column3: The poor, poor Queen!

column2: But you are bound to fail, and then who will help you all, if we too are put out of the way?"
column3: But you are bound to fail, and then who will help you all, if we too are put out of the way?"

column2: We should succeed if you helped us.	We should succeed if you helped us.
column3: true

column2: At one time you used proudly to say: 'The League of The Scarlet Pimpernel has never failed.'"
column3: At one time you used proudly to say: 'The League of The Scarlet Pimpernel has never failed.'"

column2: Because it attempted nothing which it could not accomplish.	Because it attempted nothing which it could not accomplish.
column3: false

column2: But, la! since you put me on my mettle--Demm it all!
column3: But, la! since you put me on my mettle-Demm it all!

column2: I'll have to think about it!"
column3: I'll have to think about it!"

column2: And he laughed that funny, somewhat inane laugh of his, which had deceived the clever men of two countries as to his real personality.
column3: And he laughed that funny, somewhat inane laugh of his, which had deceived the clever men of two countries as to his real personality.

column2: Deroulede went up to the heavy oak desk which occupied a conspicuous place in the centre of one of the walls.
column3: Deroulede went up to the heavy oak desk which occupied a conspicuous place in the centre of one of the walls.

column2: He unlocked it and drew forth a bundle of papers.
column3: He unlocked it and drew forth a bundle of papers.

column2: Will you look through these? he asked, handing them to Sir Percy Blakeney.
column3: Will you look through these? he asked, handing them to Sir Percy Blakeney.

column2: What are they?
column3: What are they?

column2: Different schemes I have drawn up, in case my original plan should not succeed.
column3: Different schemes I have drawn up, in case my original plan should not succeed.

column2: Burn them, my friend, said Blakeney laconically.
column3: Burn them, my friend, said Blakeney laconically.

column2: Have you not yet learned the lesson of never putting your hand to paper?
column3: Have you not yet learned the lesson of never putting your hand to paper?

column2: I can't burn these.	I can't burn these.
column3: true

column2: You see, I shall not be able to have long conversations with Marie Antoinette.
column3: You see, I shall not be able to have long conversations with Marie Antoinette.

column2: I must give her my suggestions in writing, that she may study them and not fail me, through lack of knowledge of her part."
column3: I must give her my suggestions in writing, that she may study them and not fail me, through lack of knowledge of her part."

column2: Better that than papers in these times, my friend: these papers, if found, would send you, untried, to the guillotine.
column3: Better that than papers in these times, my friend: these papers, if found, would send you, untried, to the guillotine.

column2: I am careful, and, at present, quite beyond suspicion.	I am careful, and, at present, quite beyond suspicion.
column3: true

column2: Moreover, among the papers is a complete collection of passports, suitable for any character the Queen and her attendant may be forced to assume.
column3: Moreover, among the papers is a complete collection of passports, suitable for any character the Queen and her attendant may be forced to assume.

column2: It has taken me some months to collect them, so as not to arouse suspicion; I gradually got them together, on one pretence or another: now I am ready for any eventuality ..."
column3: It has taken me some months to collect them, so as not to arouse suspicion; I gradually got them together, on one pretence or another: now I am ready for any eventuality ..."

column2: He suddenly paused.
column3: He suddenly paused.

column2: A look in his friend's face had given him a swift warning.
column3: A look in his friend's face had given him a swift warning.

column2: He turned, and there in the doorway, holding back the heavy portiere, stood Juliette, graceful, smiling, a little pale, this no doubt owing to the flickering light of the unsnuffed candles.
column3: He turned, and there in the doorway, holding back the heavy portiere, stood Juliette, graceful, smiling, a little pale, this no doubt owing to the flickering light of the unsnuffed candles.

column2: So young and girlish did she look in her soft, white muslin frock that at sight of her the tension in Deroulede's face seemed to relax. Instinctively he had thrown the papers back into the desk, but his look had softened, from the fire of obstinate energy to that of inexpressible tenderness.
column3: So young and girlish did she look in her soft, white muslin frock that at sight of her the tension in Deroulede's face seemed to relax. Instinctively he had thrown the papers back into the desk, but his look had softened, from the fire of obstinate energy to that of inexpressible tenderness.

column2: Blakeney was quietly watching the young girl as she stood in the doorway, a little bashful and undecided.
column3: Blakeney was quietly watching the young girl as she stood in the doorway, a little bashful and undecided.

column2: Madame Deroulede sent me, she said hesitatingly, "she says the hour is getting late and she is very anxious.
column3: Madame Deroulede sent me, she said hesitatingly, "she says the hour is getting late and she is very anxious.

column2: M. Deroulede, would you come and reassure her?"
column3: M. Deroulede, would you come and reassure her?"

column2: In a moment, mademoiselle, he replied lightly, "my friend and I have just finished our talk.
column3: In a moment, mademoiselle, he replied lightly, "my friend and I have just finished our talk.

column2: May I have the honour to present him?--Sir Percy Blakeney, a traveller from England.
column3: May I have the honour to present him?--Sir Percy Blakeney, a traveller from England.

column2: Blakeney, this is Mademoiselle Juliette de Marny, my mother's guest."
column3: Blakeney, this is Mademoiselle Juliette de Marny, my mother's guest."
